questions.question: Which of the following statements about medicolegal autopsy is wrong?

options.C: Requisition from police or magistrate is required
options.D: Objective reporting to the police or magistrate is required

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Consent of kin is required Explanation: Consent of kin is not required for medicolegal autopsy but is required for pathological autopsy. Medicolegal autopsy/necropsy/postmortem examination - specialized scientific examination of a deceased body conducted primarily for legal purposes. A complete autopsy is a detailed examination of the entire body, both internally and externally, including the brain, chest and abdominal organs, and musculoskeletal systems. Objectives Identification and determination of cause and time of death For newborn infants, determine whether the child was born alive and viable For mutilated, fragmented, or skeletal remains, determine if they are human, the probable cause of death, and the time since death Restore the body to the best possible cosmetic condition before releasing it to relatives Essential Requirements Performed by a registered medical practitioner with specialized training or experience in forensic medicine (forensic pathology) Meticulous examination Complete autopsy (Option A ruled out) Materials sent to forensic science laboratory Preservation of records and evidence Objective reporting to the police or magistrate is required. (Option D ruled out) Consent of kin is not required (Option B) Requisition from police or magistrate (Option C ruled out) Reference: Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th Edition, Pages 94-95, 104

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding clinical autopsy is false?

options.D: Tests are done in a medical laboratory

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Always complete Explanation: Clinical autopsy can be partial or complete Clinical/Pathological Autopsy: Conducted to determine the cause of death Requires consent from the next of kin or relatives (Option A ruled out) Requested by a clinician (Option B ruled out) The autopsy report is provided to the clinician Necessary tests are done in the concerned medical laboratory (Option D ruled out) Complete or partial autopsy, depending on the consent given (Option C) Reference: Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th Edition, Page 104

questions.question: Given below are a few statements on various kinds of autopsy. Which of them is true? A psychological autopsy is done after suicide. Virtopsy combines 2D surface scanning/CAD photogrammetry with radiologic imaging like MRI. Psychological autopsy involves data collection. The ability to identify the infection status of antemortem from postmortem wounds is limited in Virtopsy. Easy to identify postmortem artifacts using Virtopsy
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All except 2 and 5 Explanation: Virtual autopsy/Virtopsy Virtopsy is a non-invasive alternative to traditional autopsy using imaging instead of physical dissection. Technology Utilizes 3D surface scanning, MSCT, MRI, and CAD photogrammetry to create a digital, objective record. (Option D) This can be shared online for secondary opinions and presented as evidence in court if required. Features Provides high-resolution, colored 3D images in various sections Allows visualization of body surfaces, deeper tissues, organs, coronary vessels, pulmonary emboli, soft tissue trauma, and bone injuries Limitations High cost of equipment Radiologic imaging limitations, interference from metal Limited ability to distinguish internal organ colors Incomplete database for diagnosis Challenges in identifying infection status , antemortem vs. postmortem wounds (Options B and C ruled out) Difficulty in identifying postmortem artifacts and subtle tissue injuries, and differentiating certain pathological conditions (Option D) Psychological autopsy - Meticulous collection of data after someone’s suicide to understand the circumstances of their death. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7126/#:~:text=Studies%20involving%20psychological%20auto psy%20gather,if%20any%2C%20negative%20elements%20in Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th Edition, Page 134

questions.question: 2-5% of autopsies cannot determine the cause of death even after extensive lab investigations. What are such autopsies called?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Negative autopsy Explanation: In a negative autopsy, the cause of death remains unknown Obscure autopsy (Option A ruled out) Negative autopsy (Option B) The cause of death may not be clear at the time of dissection but can often be determined after detailed clinical, and laboratory investigations, and interviews Examples: Epilepsy, reflex vagal inhibition, uremia, and anesthetic overdose The cause of death remains unknown even after extensive laboratory investigations Occurs in 2-5% of all postmortem cases Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 116

questions.question: A 60-year-old male patient was found deceased under unknown circumstances, and a detailed autopsy was requested to investigate possible causes of death. During the procedure, the police surgeon decided to use an evisceration technique that involves dissecting and examining each organ system individually rather than removing the organs as a whole. Which of the following techniques is he most likely using?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gohn Explanation: Evisceration techniques in autopsy: En Masse (Letulle) (Option A ruled out) Removing most internal organs in one full swoop Rapid technique Dissection afterward is lengthy Leaves all attachments intact Virchow’s Method (Option D ruled out) Organs are removed individually Useful if the pathological focus is on a single organ In Situ Dissection (Rokitansky) (Option B ruled out) Organs are dissected within the body with minimal evisceration Rarely performed, but useful in cases involving highly transmissible diseases En block (Ghon) (Option C) Separate block dissection and organ separation Relatively quick Preserves most important inter-organ relationships Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Pages 103-104

questions.question: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy on a middle-aged female. The case requires a thorough examination of the thoracic and abdominal organs while maintaining an aesthetic appearance for potential display. Which incision technique is most appropriate to ensure optimal exposure of internal organs and accommodate forensic display requirements?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Modified Y-shaped incision Explanation In forensic autopsies, the modified Y-shaped incision is preferable when: Aesthetic appearance is important (e.g., in cases where the body will be displayed). Thorough exposure of thoracic and abdominal organs is required. There is a need to preserve the appearance of the neck and face , especially in females. Comparison of Incisions: Incision Type Description Use Case I-shaped incision (Option A) Straight vertical cut from suprasternal notch to pubic symphysis Rarely used, limited exposure Y-shaped incision (Option B) From acromion processes to xiphoid, then midline to pubic symphysis Standard in adult autopsies Modified Y-shaped (Option C) Oblique cuts below the breasts (avoiding neck), then midline down Preferred for aesthetic preservation in females T-shaped incision (Option D) Horizontal cut across shoulders + vertical cut down Used when more exposure of neck and shoulders is needed

questions.question: A 35-year-old male is found dead in his apartment under suspicious circumstances. Upon initial external examination, petechial hemorrhages are noted around the eyes. The scene suggests a possible asphyxial death, as there are no overt signs of trauma. During the autopsy by the police surgeon, which among the following has to be opened first to identify definitive signs of asphyxia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cranial cavity Explanation: In cases of suspected asphyxial death, the cranial cavity is typically opened first. The order of opening is the cranium, Thorax (Option A), abdomen, and neck. (To get a clear field of study for neck structures after draining of blood from neck vessels via the head and trunk) Asphyxial deaths frequently involve abnormalities in the lungs and airway, such as congestion, petechiae, froth in the airways, or other indicators of respiratory failure. This helps confirm if the cause of death is indeed related to impaired oxygen exchange or suffocation. Examining the heart may also reveal signs of right-sided heart failure due to hypoxia. Abdomen is first to be opened in stillbirth Order of Opening Cavities Head Injury Cases, Asphyxial Deaths The skull opened before the thorax and abdomen. Pneumothorax, Venous air embolism The Thorax opened first, then the skull. Abdominal cavity (Option B): While the abdominal cavity could be opened to assess for trauma or distension, these findings are less likely to provide direct clues in cases of asphyxia unless abdominal trauma is suspected, which is not indicated here. Thus, it is typically examined after the thoracic cavity. Pelvic cavity (Option D): Trauma to the pelvic organs or fractures is more relevant in cases involving physical injury or sexual assault. These findings are not directly associated with asphyxial deaths, so this cavity is not examined first. Reference: Parikh's Textbook of Medical Jurisprudence, Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 8th edition, page 107 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10198145/

questions.question: A 28-year-old man is found dead at home and poisoning is suspected. During the autopsy, the forensic pathologist decides to dissect the stomach to examine its contents. Which of the following is the most appropriate procedure for stomach dissection to preserve evidence of poisoning and ensure accurate forensic analysis?

options.A: Open the stomach along the greater curvature and discard the contents
options.B: Open the stomach along the lesser curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
options.C: Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology
options.D: Incise the stomach along the pylorus and drain the contents into the small intestine

questions.explanation: toxicology Correct Answer: C) Open the stomach along the greater curvature and collect the contents for toxicology Explanation : In forensic autopsies, the stomach is usually opened along the greater curvature to minimize disruption of stomach anatomy and allows the pathologist to collect and examine the stomach contents effectively, which is critical in cases of suspected poisoning. Procedure for Stomach Dissection: Two ligatures are applied at the cardiac end of the esophagus and two ligatures are below the pyloric end of the stomach. The stomach is removed by cutting between the double ligatures at both ends. The stomach is then opened along the greater curvature . The mucous membrane is examined for the presence of any stains, congestion, hemorrhage, desquamation, ulceration, sloughing, or perforation. The contents of the stomach are noted with respect to quantity, nature of material/food, state of digestion, color, and smell. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, Pages 104-110

questions.question: A 45-year-old man was found dead under suspicious circumstances, and his body was buried without a post-mortem examination. Months later, new evidence suggests foul play, and the family now requests further investigation. The local police inspector wishes to exhume the body to re-examine the cause of death. Which of the following authorities is legally empowered to order an exhumation in this case? A) Police Inspector B) First Class Magistrate C) Sub-Inspector of Police D) Medical Officer E) Sub-Divisional Magistrate
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Only B and E Explanation : In India, only specific magistrates can order exhumation: First Class, District, Sub-Divisional, Executive Magistrates. Law enforcement cannot order exhumation independently. Exhumation Legal disinterment of a previously buried body. Conducted when post-burial examination is necessary. Common Reasons Criminal Cases: Re-examine suspected homicides disguised as suicides/accidents. Investigate deaths from criminal abortion or negligence. Retrieve evidence (e.g., bullets). Civil Cases: Insurance/worker's compensation claims. Professional negligence cases. Inheritance disputes or identity verification. Correct burial errors (If the wrong body was buried) Procedure Requirements Timing & Personnel: Must be conducted during daylight (start in the morning). A medical officer, magistrate, and police officer are required. Documentation: Verify grave location and markers. Collect soil samples (above, below, and beside the body/coffin). Document body position and appearance. Create a detailed grave diagram. Photograph grave, coffin, and body. Handling Guidelines Avoid altering the body (no use of disinfectants or pesticides). Use plank or plastic sheet for removal if decomposition is minimal. Transport the body to the mortuary for post-mortem examination. Reference: Goutam Biswas Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd edition, pages 119, 120

questions.question: A 45-year-old man who had been incarcerated for political dissent is reported to have died under suspicious circumstances. The autopsy reveals multiple injuries consistent with physical torture. In considering international guidelines for the medical investigation of such cases, which key document outlines principles and standards for identifying and investigating torture for a Police Surgeon?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Istanbul Protocol Explanation : Istanbul Protocol Official name: UN Manual on the Effective Investigation and Documentation of Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment Key international guideline for the medical and legal investigation of torture Provides detailed procedures for documenting: Physical evidence of torture Psychological consequences of torture Widely used by: Forensic experts Human rights investigators Police surgeons Essential in cases of custodial death , political torture , and ill-treatment Not to be confused with the Declaration of Istanbul , which deals with organ trafficking Declaration of Istanbul (Clarification) Focus: Organ trafficking and transplant tourism Provides ethical guidance on: Organ donation Prevention of illegal organ trade Not related to torture documentation or custodial deaths Comparison of International Declarations Declaration / Document Focus / Purpose Istanbul Protocol Documentation and investigation of torture and ill-treatment Declaration of Tokyo Guidelines for doctors on torture related to detention and imprisonment (Option A ruled out) Declaration of Helsinki Ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects (Option C ruled out) Nuremberg Code Ethics in human experimentation post-WWII (Option D ruled out) Geneva Conventions Treatment of combatants and civilians during armed conflict Declaration of Malta Guidelines on physicians’ roles during hunger strikes , especially in custodial settings Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1879451/?page=1 Launch of the revised version on the Istanbul Protocol - PubMed The Geneva Convention: Humanitarian law and medicine The Declaration of Helsinki - PMC The Nuremberg Code–A critique - PMC https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28989165/

questions.question: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) El Plantón Explanation: The given image depicts El Planton Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic, or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason. Physical torture subtypes Types of Torture Description El Plantón (Option D) Victim is forced to stand for extended periods in the ‘Army Corps’ poster or body folding or on one leg. Dependent edema and petechiae. Scaphism (Option A) An ancient form of execution involving being trapped between two boats and subjected to insects and exposure. Dry Submarine (Option B) Form of suffocation where the victim's head is wrapped in a plastic bag, causing breathing

questions.question: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Belana Explanation: The given image depicts Belana Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason. Physical torture subtypes Types of torture Description Belana or The roller (Option B) The pole is placed on the back of the victim and is pressed down with great weight and then rolled up over the legs and the body. Crushing of soft tissue and damage to muscles of the legs and the body. Chepuwa (Option A) The thighs of the victim are placed under two wooden rods and pressed to induce severe pain. Sawhorse or ‘el cabellete’ (Option C) Forced straddling on a sharp object like a saw. Perineal bruising was seen. Operating table or ‘el quirofano’ (Option D) Beating on the abdomen while lying on a table with the upper half of the body unsupported. Bruise, ruptured abdominal viscera.

questions.question: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Telefono Explanation: The given image depicts Telefono Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason. Physical torture subtypes Types of torture Description Telefono/Ear torture (Option A) Repeated and simultaneous slapping of both the ears by open hands of the torturer. Ruptured tympanic membrane. Falanga or Bastinado (Option B) Most common form of torture. Victim is suspended upside down and then beaten on the soles by blunt instruments such as sticks, clubs or rifle butts. Haematoma of the soles. Passing the board or Beating buttocks (Option C) Victim is forced to the ground and beaten viciously with the board club or baton on the buttock. Nail torture (Option D) Victims' nails (either fingernails or toenails) are subjected to various forms of abuse, such as being pulled out, crushed, or having sharp objects driven under them.

questions.question: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Parrot Perch Explanation: The given image depicts Parrot Perch Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason. Physical torture subtypes Types of torture Description La Bandera (Option A) Involves hanging the victim by their wrists, often with weights attached to the feet, causing intense pain in the arms and shoulders. Nerve and muscle damage with joint injuries seen. Parrot Perch/Jack or ‘Pau de arara’ (Option B) Victim is suspended head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with the wrist bound to the ankles. Crucifixion/Palestine hanging (Option C) The victim is nailed or tied to a cross, leaving them to hang in an agonizing position, often leading to death by asphyxiation or exhaustion. Jack Knife Position (Option D) The victim is bent forward, usually with their legs straight and their upper body folded down toward the knees, causing muscle cramps and restricted breathing.

questions.question: What is the type of torture mentioned in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Wet Submarine Explanation: The given image depicts a Wet Submarine Torture: Defined as deliberate, systemic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority to force another person to yield information or for any other reason. Physical torture subtypes Types of torture Description Wet Submarine (Option A) Involves submerging the victim's head in water or a similar liquid to create a sensation of drowning. Fecal matter and other debris in the airways. Black Slave (Option B) Hot metal skewer is inserted up the anus of the victim. Perianal and rectal burns were seen. Iron Chair/Confession chair /Interrogation chair (Option C) The victim is tied to an iron chair equipped with either wooden or iron spikes, which could be heated from below. Judas cradle (Option D) The victim is first stripped and then suspended over a pointed pyramid. The torture using ropes and pulleys, used to raise and lower the victim so that the point would penetrate the anus, vagina or scrotum.
